title: The highest neutron to proton ratio

content.question:
When a californium (<math alttext="californium"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>Cf</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>) nucleus undergoes spontaneous fission, the following two reactions occur, where <math alttext="X"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Y"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are unidentified nuclei.

<math alttext="Step 1: californium-252 with atomic number 98 produces X plus ruthenium-108 with atomic number 44 plus 4 neutrons."><mstyle><mrow><mmultiscripts><mrow><mtext>Cf</mtext></mrow><mprescripts><mrow><mn>98</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>252</mn></mrow></mprescripts></mmultiscripts><mo>→</mo><mtext>X</mtext><mo>+</mo><mmultiscripts><mrow><mtext>Ru</mtext></mrow><mprescripts><mrow><mn>44</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>108</mn></mrow></mprescripts></mmultiscripts><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mmultiscripts><mrow><mtext>n</mtext></mrow><mprescripts><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mprescripts></mmultiscripts></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="Step 2: X produces Y plus beta with negative 1 charge"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mo>→</mo><mtext>Y</mtext><mo>+</mo><mmultiscripts><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><mprescripts><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mprescripts></mmultiscripts></mrow></mstyle></math>

Which nucleus in the pair of equations has the greatest neutron-to-proton ratio?

topic.text: 15.2: The Bohr Model of Atomic Structure

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
